title: Complex Bingham distributions: An exponential family with a sufficient statistic which is quadratic in the data. Such distributions provide tractable models for landmark-based shape analysis

container-title: Design and Analysis of Cross-Over trials
title: Cox^Plackettmodel: A logistic regression model for the marginal probabilities from a 2 × 2 crossover trial with a binary outcome measure

container-title: Random Number Generation and Monte Carlo Methods
title: Craps test: A test for assessing the quality of random number generators
Credible region: Synonym for Bayesian confidence interval
Criss-cross design: Synonym for strip-plot design

note: Cycles, the Mysterious Forces that Trigger Events, 1971, E. R. Dewey, Hawthorn Books, New York.
title: Cycle: A term used when referring to time series for a periodic movement of the series. The period is the time it takes for one complete up-and-down and down-and-up movement
Data matrix: See multivariate data
Monitoring Committees in Clinical Trials: A Practical Perspective
Data vizualization: Interpretable graphical representations of abstract data and their relationships. See also statistical graphics

container-title: See also ACE model. [Annual Review of Psychology
title: DeFries^Fulker analysis: A class of regression models that can be used to provide possible estimates of the fundamental biometrical genetic constructs, heritability and shared or common environment
Delayed entry: In survival analysis this refers to situations where units do not come under observation when they become at risk for the event of interest but instead after a delay

container-title: Demography: Measuring and Modeling Population Processes
title: Demography: The study of human populations with respect to their size, structure and dynamics, by statistical methods
Dentonmethod: A widely used method for benchmarking a time series to annual benchmarks while preserving as far as possible the month-to-month movement of the original series
Design set: Synonym for training set
Deviance residuals: The signed square root of an observation’s contribution to total model deviance

container-title: Residuals and Influence in Regression, 1994, R.D. Cook and S
title: Diagnostics: Procedures for indentifying departures from assumptions when fitting statistical models. See, for example, DFBETA and DFFITS
When the dropout mechanism is informative the probability of dropout at time t can depend on the unobserved yt . See also missing values and selection models
Discrete time Markov chain: See Markov chain

Dodge’s continuous sampling plan: A procedure for monitoring continuous production processes

publisher: T.M. Therneau and P.M. Grambsch, Springer
title: Doob^Meyer decomposition: A theorem which shows that any counting process may be uniquely decomposed as the sum of a martingale and a predictable, right-continous process called the compensator, assuming certain mathematical conditions
Dunn’s test: A multiple comparison test based on the Bonferroni correction. [Biostatistics: A Methodology for the Health Sciences
Dutch book: A gamble that gives rise to certain loss, no matter what actually occurs. Used as a rhetorical device in subjective probability and Bayesian statistics

location: Cleveland and M.E. McGill, Wadsworth, Belmont, California
title: Dynamic graphics: Computer graphics for the exploration of multivariate data which allow the observations to be rotated and viewed from all directions. Particular sets of observations can be highlighted. Often useful for discovering structure or pattern, for example, the presence of clusters. See also brushing scatterplots

Ecological statistics: Procedures for studying the dynamics of natural communities and their relation to environmental variables
Empirical distribution function: A probability distribution function estimated directly from sample data without assuming an underlying algebraic form

note: P. Millard, N. K. Neerchal, CRC Press, Boca Raton.
title: Environmental statistics: Procedures for determining how quality of life is affected by the environment, in particular by such factors as air and water pollution, solid wastes, hazardous substances, foods and drugs
Epidemic chain: See chains of infection

container-title: The Mathematical Theory of Infectious Diseases
title: Epidemic threshold: The value above which the susceptible population size has to be for an epidemic to become established in a population

title: Epi Info: Free software for performing basic sample size calculations, developing a study questionnaire, performing statistical analyses, etc

note: See also LISREL. [Distributor is Multivariate Software:
title: EQS: A software package for fitting structural equation models

Evidence-based medicine (EBM): Described by its leading proponent as ‘the conscientious, explicit, and judicious uses of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients, and integrating individual clinical experience with the best available external clinical evidence from systematic research’

Experimental design: The arrangement and procedures used in an experimental study. Some general principles of good design are, simplicity, avoidance of bias, the use of random allocation for forming treatment groups, replication and adequate sample size
Father wavelet: See wavelet functions

container-title: Modelling Covariance and Latent Variables using EQS
title: Multiple indicator multiple cause model (MIMIC): A structural equation model in which there are multiple indicators and multiple causes of each latent variable
MULTISCALE: Software for multidimensional scaling set in an inferential framework
Department of Psychology, McGill University, Steward Biological Sciences Building, 1205 Dr
Multivariate probit analysis: A method for assessing the effect of explanatory variables on a set of two or more correlated binary response variables. See also probit analysis

note: OX2 8DR; NAG Inc., 1431 Opus Place, Suite 220, Downers Grove, Illinois 60515-1362, USA; www.nag.co.uk
publisher: NAG Ltd., Wilkinson House, Jordan Hill Road
title: NAG: Numerical Algorithms Group producing many useful subroutines relevant to statistics
Non-Gaussian time series: Time series, often not stationary with respect to both mean and period, which exhibit a non-Gaussian random component

publisher: Davis and P. Rabinowitz, Academic Press
title: Numerical integration: The study of how the numerical value of an integral can be found. Also called quadrature which refers to finding a square whose area is the same as the area under a curve. See also Simpson’s rule, Gaussian quadrature and trapeziodal rule
Observed-score equating: The practice of transforming observed scores on different forms of (usually) a cognitive test to a common normal distribution
See also clustered data, generalized estimating equations and mixed-effects logistic regression
Population genetics: The study of the distributions of genes in populations across space and time, and the factors that influence these distributions
Population weighting adjustments: A procedure for making estimates of the quantities of interest in a sample survey representative of a given population rather than the one actually sampled
Quality function: See quality-adjusted survival analysis
Quantit model: A three-parameter non-linear logistic regression model
death rate of interest

note: He died on June 2nd, 1966 in Moscow.
title: Born in Moscow, Russia, Smirnov graduated from the University of Moscow in 1926 and then taught at Moscow University, Timoryazev Agricultural Academy and Moscow City Pedagogical Institute. In 1938 he obtained his doctorate with his dissertation, ‘On approximation of the distribution of random variables’. From 1938 until his death Smirnov worked at the Steklov Mathematical Institute of the USSR Academy of Sciences in Moscow making significant contributions to the distributions of statistics used in nonparametric tests and the limiting distributions of order statistics

container-title: See also nQuery advisor. [Statistical Solutions, 8 South Bank
title: SOLO: A computer package for calculating sample sizes to achieve a particular power for a variety of different research designs
Sortedbinary plot: A graphical method for identifying and displaying patterns in multivariate data sets
Spatial data: A collection of measurements or observations on one or more variables taken at specified locations and for which the spatial organization of the data is of primary interest

Spatialexperiment: A comparative experiment in which experimental units occupy fixed locations distributed throughout a region in one-, two- or three-dimensional space. Such experiments are most common in agriculture

container-title: Communications in Statistics – Theory and Methods
title: Spearman^Kärberestimator: An estimator of the median effective dose in bioassays having a binary variable as a response
Spectral density matrix: See multiple time series

note: Sphericity: See Mauchly test. Sphericity test: Synonym for Mauchly test.
title: Spectral radius: A term sometimes used for the size of the largest eigenvalue of a variance–covariance matrix. Spectrum: See spectral analysis. Spherical variable: An angular measure confined to be on the unit sphere. Figure 129 shows a representation of such a variable

note: Spiegelman died on 25 March 1969 in New York.
title: Born in Brooklyn, New York, Spiegelman received a masters of engineering degree from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn in 1923 and a masters of business administration degree from Harvard University in 1925. He worked for 40 years for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Office and made important contributions to biostatistics particularly in the areas of demography and public health
Splicing: A refined method of smoothing out local peaks and troughs, while retaining the broad ones, in data sequences contaminated with noise

Staggered entry: A term used when subjects are entered into a study at times which are related to their own disease history (e.g, immediately following diagnosis) but which are unpredictable from the point-of-view of the study
Structural Time series Analyser, Modeller and Predictor, software for constructing a wide range of structural time series models

publisher: USA; Timberlake Consultants, Unit B3, Broomsley Business Park, Worsley Bridge Rd
title: STATA: A comprehensive software package for many forms of statistical analysis; particularly useful for epidemiological and longitudinal data. [STATA Corporation, 4905 Lakeway Drive

publisher: M. T. Wasson, Cambridge University Press
title: Stochastic approximation: A procedure for finding roots of equations when these roots are observable in the presence of statistical variation

note: S.Kotz, C. B. Read, N.Balakrishnan and B.Vidakovic, Wiley, New York.
title: Suppressor variables: A variable in a regression analysis that is not correlated with the dependent variable, but that is still useful for increasing the size of the multiple correlation coefficient by virtue of its correlations with other explanatory variables. The variable ‘suppresses’ variance that is irrelevant to prediction of the dependent variable
Survey: Synonym for sample survey
Therapeutic trial: Synonym for clinical trial

note: He died on September 26th, 1910 in Copenhagen.
title: Born in Copenhagen, Denmark, Thiel studies Astronomy at the University of Copenhagen and became Professor of Astronomy and Director of the Copenhagen Observatory in 1875. He founded the Danish Society of Actuaries in 1901 and served as its president. Thiel’s main contributions to statistics were in the areas of skew distributions and cumulants

container-title: Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B
title: Time-dependent covariates: Covariates whose values change over time as opposed to covariates whose values remain constant over time (time-independent covariates). A pretreatment measure of some characteristic is an example of the latter, age and weight, examples of the former

container-title: See also Chow-Williams distribution and Wigner-Ville distribution. [Proceedings of the IEEE
title: Time-frequency distribution: A description of the energy or power of a signal as a twodimensional function of both time and frequency. Such distributions are used to study nonstationary time series
Tobit model: Synonym for censored regression model

container-title: SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications
title: Toeplitz matrix: A matrix in which the element in the ith row and jth column depends only on ji jj. The variance–covariance matrices of stationary series have this property

Townsend index: An index designed to measure material deprivation of an area. The index is calculated as an unweighted sum of four standardized census variables corresponding to area-level proportions of unemployment, car ownership, crowding and home ownership

note: Microeconometrics, 2005, A. C. Cameron and P. K. Trivedi, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.
title: where y1 and x1 are the subsample averages of the y and x variables when z=1, and y0 and x0 are the corresponding values when z=0
procedure has very broad asymptotic near-optimality properties

container-title: Journal of the American Statistical Association
title: Wei^Lachin test: A distribution free method for the equality of two multivariate distributions. Most often used in the analysis of longitudinal data with missing observations
White’shomoscedasticity test: A test that assesses whether the error term in a linear regression model has a constant variance

container-title: Communication in Statistics: Simulation and Computation
title: Whittle likelihood: An approximate likelihood function used to estimate the spectral density and certain parameters of a variety of time series models
WGEE: Abbreviation for weighted generalized estimating equations
Williams’ designs: A type of latin square which requires fewer observations to achieve balance when there are more than three treatments
the Chambers Medal of the Royal Statistical Society for his contributions and work for the society
Statistical Analysis of Circular Data
Wrappeddistribution: A probability distribution on the real line that has been wrapped around the circle of unit radius. If X is the original random variable, the random variable after ‘wrapping
See also wrapped normal distribution

note: Zero-truncated Poisson distribution: See Zero-truncated probability distributions.

title: ZIP: Abbreviation for zero-inflated Poisson regression
